citations.narrative:
1. Critical item: In June 2024 two 13-lined ground squirrels sustained degloving injuries to their tails, which this species is
predisposed to, during cage change that resulted in amputation of the distal part of their tails. The animals had arrived at
the facility less than one week prior. Technicians were following the standard operating procedure used with this species
for cage changes that minimizes direct handling of these fast-moving and jumpy small sized rodents. A PVC tube is used
to scoop the animal inside one end, technician blocks the open ends of the tube with their hands, and the tube containing
the squirrel is then placed in the new cage. The tail of one animal was injured when it became caught between the edge
of the tube and the hand of the technician and the tail of the second animal was injured when the technician grasped the
lower body and part of its tail when it suddenly tried to escape. In each instance, technicians immediately contacted
veterinary staff who examined and treated the animals. Both squirrels recovered uneventfully.
Per this Section, the handling of animals by all personnel should be done as carefully as possible in a manner that does
not cause behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. The two squirrels sustained degloving injuries to
their tail during handling for cage change that subsequently resulted in tail amputation. The research facility addressed
this incident prior to the inspection by refresher training in husbandry and handling practices. No additional incidents have
occurred. To remain corrected from this date 8/7/24 forward.
2. Non-critical item: On the morning of 5/18/24 facility personnel found one marmoset was outside its enclosure on the top
of another enclosure and was observed fighting with the two marmosets that were inside that enclosure. The loose
marmoset was caught and returned to its enclosure. The lower lift door of its enclosure was open, and it was determined
that the door had not been secured by personnel. Veterinary staff were immediately contacted to assess and examine the
marmosets. All animals in the room were checked and only one animal was found to have injuries. The marmoset that
escaped and one of the animals in the cage that it was on top of were uninjured. The second marmoset inside that
enclosure sustained bite wounds to two fingers of one hand, the wounds were treated and healed uneventfully.
Per this Section, the handling of animals by all personnel should be done as carefully as possible in a manner that does
not cause physical harm, behavioral stress, or unnecessary discomfort. The marmoset sustained injuries to its hand when
a marmoset housed in another enclosure was able to escape its enclosure after one of the doors to its enclosure not
being secured by personnel. The research facility addressed this incident prior to the inspection by refresher training in
husbandry and handling practices. No additional incidents have occurred. To remain corrected from this date 8/7/24
forward.
This inspection was conducted with facility representatives from 8/5/24 through 8/7/24. The exit briefing was held with
facility representatives on 8/7/24.
*END OF REPORT*
